direction.raw_text: . Delicatessens hang on the walls, wreathed with garlands of garlic. PATSY, the boss, a swarthy man of sixty, is flopping a chunk of beef onto the scale for the benefit of a forty- year-old MATRON. There are three or four other WOMEN in the shop, all talking to one another. A four-year-old BOY lazily chases a cat. The white refrigerator room door opens, and a second butcher, MARTY PILLETTI, comes out carrying a large leg of lamb. Marty is a mildmannered, short, stout, balding man of thirty-four. His charm lies in an almost indestructible good humor. He drops the leg of lamb onto the chopping block, reaches up for the cleaver hanging with the other utensils over the block and makes quick incisive cuts into the leg of lamb. He sets the cleaver aside, picks up the saw to finish the cuts as he chats with his customer, MRS. FUSARI.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty sets the five chops on the scale, watches its weight register.

direction.raw_text: . Clara sits about halfway down the length of the booths. Dr. Keegan and the Stag stand over her, talking to her. She is looking up at them, her hands nervously gripping a Coca Cola glass. Dr. Keegan is obviously introducing the Stag to Clara and is going through some story about being called away on an emergency. The Stag is presented as her escort-to-be, who will see to it that she gets home safely. Clara is not taken in by any of this, although she is trying hard not to seem affected. She politely rejects the Stag's company and will go home by herself, thanks for asking anyway. Dr. Keegan makes a few mild protestations, and then he and the Stag leave the booth and start back toward the archway.

dialogue.raw_text: You come up here often?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was up here twice before. Once with a friend of mine and once I came up alone. The last time... do you see that girl in the gray dress sitting over there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.

dialogue.raw_text: Well, the last time I was up here, that's where I sat. I sat there for an hour and a half, without moving a muscle. Now and then, some fellow would sort of walk up to me and then change his mind. I'll never forget just sitting there for an hour and a half with my hands in my lap. Then I began to cry, and I had to get up and go home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I cry a lot too. I'm a big cryer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is something recent with me, this bursting into tears at the least thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I cry all the time, any little thing. My brothers, my brother-in- laws, they're always telling me what a goodhearted guy I am. Well, you don't get goodhearted by accident. You get kicked around long enough, you get to be a real professor of pain. I know exactly how you feel. And I also want you to know I'm having a very good time with you now and really enjoying myself. So you see, you're not such a dog as you think you are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm having a very good time, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So there you are. So I guess I'm not such a dog as I think I am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a very nice guy, and I don't know why some girl hasn't grabbed you off long ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know either. I think I'm a very nice guy. I also think I'm a pretty smart guy in my own way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now I figure, two people get married, and they gonna live together forty, fifty years. So it's just gotta be more than whether they're good looking or not. You tell me you think you're not very good-looking. My father was a really ugly man, but my mother adored him. She told me that she used to get so miserable sometimes, like everybody, you know? And she says my father always tried to understand. I used to see them sometimes when I was a kid, sitting in the living room, talking and talking, and I used to adore my old man, because he was so kind. That's one of the most beautiful things I have in my life, the way my father and mother were. And my father was a real ugly man. So it doesn't matter if you look like a gorilla. So you see, dogs like us, we ain't such dogs as we think we are.

dialogue.raw_text: I'm twenty-nine years old. How old are you?

dialogue.raw_text: I'm thirty-four.

Der, die, das -- des, der, des. There you are, I still remember...

dialogue.raw_text: Two o'clock in the morning he died. The doorbell rings, and I knew something was wrong right away. Because my room is onna ground floor inna front, you see, and I got outta bed, and I answered the door...

direction.raw_text: Marty stares at Clara, absolutely aghast at his inability to stop talking.

dialogue.raw_text: There was Mr. Stern. He had a house down about a block from us. He moved out though. My old man, he used to play cards with him and some other old guys. He's a Jewish feller. So he said, "Is your mother home?" So I knew right away there was something wrong. I was only eighteen, exactly eighteen years old, just the month before. So I said, "Is something wrong, Mr. Stern?" I was in my pajamas, you know? So he said, "Marty, your father died." My father died right inna middle of playing cards, right at the table. He had a heart attack. He had low blood pressure, my old man. He used to faint a lot.

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. Once a candy store, now a soda fountain where booths have been installed in the rear. One wall of the luncheonette in front is covered with magazines from floor to ceiling. It is a nice clean joint, brightly lit. Several CUSTOMERS are occupying three of the four booths.

direction.raw_text: . They sit opposite each other in the booth. Each has a cup of coffee. Marty is still talking, but now he is apparently telling a story so funny that he can hardly get the words out. The hilarity has communicated itself to Clara. Her eyes are burning with suppressed laughter. Every now and then she has to gasp to control the bubbly giggling inside of her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has to interrupt the narrative to control a seizure of giggles. Clara wipes her eyes and catches her breath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He can't go on. He has to stop and cover his face with one hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's too much for him. He lets out a sudden guffaw and instantly smothers it under shaking shoulders. Clara hides her face in her hands and giggles desperately. Some of the other people turn to look at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stares at the girl, spent from laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He closes his eyes, shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For a moment they seem to have controlled their laughter. They sit, shaking their heads, studying their fingers on the table in front of them. Then slowly, Marty begins to giggle again. It communicates itself to Clara. In a moment they are hiding their faces in their hands, their shoulders shivering with laughter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...When I got outta the army, Clara, I was lost. I didn't know what I wanted to do. I was twenny-five years old, what was I gonna do, go back to my old job, forty cents an hour. I thought maybe I go to college under the G.I. Biller Rights, you know? But I wouldn't graduate till I was twenny-eight, twenny-nine years old, even if I made it in three years. And my brother Freddie wanted to get married, and I had three unmarried sisters -- in an Italian home, that's a terrible thing. And my kid brother Nickie, he's a one got married last week. So I just went to pieces. I used to walk inna streets till three, four o'clock inna mornings. My mother used to be so worried about me. My uncle Mario come over one time. He offered me a job driving his hack onna night shift. He got his own cab, you know. And God forgive me for what I'm gonna say now, but I used to thinka doing away with myself. I used to stand sometimes in the subway, and God forgive me what I'm going to say, I used to feel the tracks sucking me down under the wheels.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (deeply sympathetic) Yes, I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm a Catholic, you know, and even to think about suicide is a terrible sin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I know.

dialogue.raw_text: So then Mr. Gazzara -- he was a frienda my father -- he offered me this job in his butcher shop, and everybody pleaded with me to take it. So that's what happened. I didn't wanna be a butcher.

dialogue.raw_text: There's nothing wrong with being a butcher.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I wouldn't call it an elegant profession. It's in a lower social scale. People look down on butchers.

dialogue.raw_text: I don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, the point is Mr. Gazzara wantsa sell his shop now, because he and his wife are lonely, and they wanna move out to California in Los Angeles and live near their married daughter. Because she's always writing them to come out there. So it's a nice little shop. I handle his books for him, so I know he has a thirty-five percent markup which is not unreasonable, and he takes home net maybe a hundred, hundred and fifty bucks a week. The point is, of course, you gotta worry about the supermarkets. There's two inna neighborhood now, and there's an A&P coming in, at least that's the rumor. Of course, mosta his trade is strictly Italian, but the younger Italian girls, they get married, and they don't stick to the old Italian dishes so much. I mean, you gotta take that into account too.

dialogue.raw_text: It's my feeling that you really want to buy this shop, Marty.

dialogue.raw_text: Marty, I know you for three hours, but I know you're a good butcher. You're an intelligent, sensitive, decent man. I have a feeling about you like sometimes a kid comes in to see me for one reason or another. And some of these kids, Marty, in my classes, they have so much warmth in them, so much capacity. Marty suddenly stops and bends down; his shoe lace has become untied. Clara sits back against the fender of the nearest car and continues talking.

direction.raw_text: of Marty marching along 176th Street. He quickly reaches the Grand Concourse. Here he pauses a moment, a little at a loss for what direction to take -- then remembers he needs the uptown bus. He moves across the wide street to get to the other side of the boulevard. Again, he seems to lose track of which direction is homeward. He walks uptown a ways with a strange jerky stride, pausing every once in a while to see whether there's a bus coming. Suddenly Marty breaks into a dog-trot, then drops back into the stiff stride as he approaches...

result.heading: THE INTERSECTION OF THE GRAND CONCOURSE

direction.raw_text: S: Marty strides, walks, stops short, goes to the curb desultorily, a few paces into the street, moves back. The traffic moves by him. He stands in the wide street, then with a gesture of magnificent expansiveness, he raises his arm and calls out.

direction.raw_text: . DAY Marty is in his trousers and T-shirt. He whistles as he assembles his toilet articles for a shave. He starts out toward the living room, still whistling. Bright sunlight pours through the curtains on his window.

direction.raw_text: . Marty's whistling accompanies him to the second floor where he turns into the bathroom. CAMERA ANGLES to include Mrs. Pilletti's bedroom, disclosing her wearing an old faded batiste kimona, puttering around her room and cleaning. As Marty's toneless tune reaches her, Mrs. Pilletti turns her head and stares off, listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. Catherine, in the living room, is packing her meager but neatly folded belongings into an old European carpet bag. She has regained her stiff, mordant crustiness. The mild WAIL of a baby can be heard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The crowded bedroom is furnished in white modern. It is cluttered by a baby's bassinet and other baby items. Virginia sits on the edge of the bed, holding the baby, quieting it. She is half-dressed, wearing her pajama top, a half-slip, no stockings; her hair is still uncombed. Thomas slouches against a chest of drawers, in morning semi-deshabille. He is obviously sick with guilt. Virginia looks anxiously at her husband then to the baby in her arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pulls his sock on angrily, then lets his leg fall back to the floor and just sits, one sock on, one sock in his hand. He looks sullenly in the direction of his wife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stands, then becomes aware he has to put on his other sock. He sits down again and pulls the second sock on. Virginia has had a hot reply in her mouth, but she forces it back. She rocks the baby a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas has risen, a slim, dark, unsettled young man in undershirt and trousers, holding his shoes in one hand. He starts toward the...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (heavy whisper) Don't you think I feel lousy about this too?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, Ginnie. I don't wanna talk anymore about it. (sits on a wooden chair, unrolls a fresh pair of socks he's been holding) I don't think I got one hour's sleep the whole night. (raises one leg to put a sock on, pauses with his heel on the edge of his chair) Last night was the first time in my life I ever heard my mother cry, you know that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tommy...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (snapping) I don't wanna talk about it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (continuing, huffy) I know what you're gonna say. A man's gotta stop being his mother's baby sooner or later. How many times you gonna say it? She's my mother, you know. I oughta have some feelings about her, don't you think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why do you always put me inna position of being the louse?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in a furious whisper) Virginia, I don't wanna hear no more about it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tommy, I love you, and I know you feel lousy right now, but we're never gonna be happy unless we have a chance to work out our own lives. We can't keep talking in whispers like this the resta our lives. We gotta have some privacy. We...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Thomas strides down the little foyer. He turns and looks into the living room. He watches his mother packing strange brown parcels into her bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The old lady nods brusquely.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (scowling) Can't you wait five minutes? I'll drive you over inna car. I just gotta put my shirt on, that's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Thomas stands with his head bowed to hide the tears he feels sweeping into his hot eyes. Then he returns to his bedroom in his stocking-feet, carrying his shoes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Thomas comes in just as Virginia bends over the bassinet, having gotten the baby back to sleep. Thomas cries to her in a furious whisper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns from her, sits down on the bed miserably angry with the world, his wife, his mother, himself. The baby begins to whimper again. Virginia turns wearily to her husband.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: All right, get dressed, because we're gonna drive my mother over. Why couldn't you get along with her?! Why couldn't you make just a little effort?! She's a little hard to get along with! All right! All I asked you was try a little.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tommy...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (roaring out) I don't wanna hear anymore about it, you hear me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY. A small procession consisting of Thomas carrying his mother's carpet bag, his mother carrying small paper-wrapped bundles, and Virginia holding the baby comes across the front hedge. Thomas leads the parade with a muffled sorrow. They turn up the porch to the front door. Virginia remains in the small front yard. She is miserable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. Mrs. Pilletti is dressed in hat and coat and all set to go to mass. She is bent over the dining room table piling the breakfast dishes and crumbing the table. She looks up as Thomas comes in carrying his mother's bag. Aunt Catherine is right behind him. Beyond the porch, we can see Virginia walking the baby around outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A burst of spirited song soars from upstairs. Mrs. Pilletti, Aunt Catherine and even Thomas pause to look up in the direction of the voice.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Aunt Theresa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . PILLETTI Hello, Thomas, how do you feel?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (setting the bag down) Ah, my mother, she drives me crazy. I hadda beg her to let me drive her over here. The martyr. She always gotta be the big martyr.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, will you go to mass, please. This one, he woke up this morning with salt in his nose. Do this! Do that! Will you leave me in peace, ah?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Marty descends the stairs whistling. He carries his jacket over his arm. He makes some final adjustments to his tie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Alert to Marty's mood, Mrs. Pilletti, Aunt Catherine and Thomas stand, waiting for him to join them downstairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He abruptly goes out into the living room and onto the front porch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty has followed Thomas out into the living room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas goes out the door onto the porch. Marty stands in the open doorway. He looks out into the warm sunshine in the front yard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes out into the yard to Virginia. He is as gay as a bird. He takes the baby from Virginia's arms, holds it high up above him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas hasn't been listening to Marty and crosses quickly to Virginia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty comes up to them, holding the baby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas has been trying to listen to Marty, but his thoughts are all with his own problem. He whirls on Virginia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The baby in Marty's arms has started to cry a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The baby starts to cry again. Thomas turns to his wife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Virginia hurries over and takes the crying baby from Marty's arms, walks around comforting the child. Thomas turns back to Marty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty is a little taken aback by Thomas's frontal assault.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty stands, watching the young couple yakking at each other. The little baby starts to cry again.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (ebulliently) Hello, Aunt Catherine! How are you? Hello, Thomas. You going to mass with us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was at mass two hours ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, make yourself at home. The refrigerator is loaded with food. Go upstairs, take any room you want. Thomas, you going to mass with us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nods) Yeah, yeah, sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . PILLETTI (to Catherine) You wanna cuppa coffee?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Boy, beautiful day, hey, Thomas?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, great if you ain't married.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi, Virginia.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to baby) Hey, little boy, you sure getting fat. You weigh more than a side-a beef now. (beams at the baby) Hey, Thomas, so I was telling you yesterday you was over my house -- Mr. Gazzara, my boss, so he wantsa sell his shop, go out to California because his kids are all married, and he...

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh shaddup, will you do me a favor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So Thomas, he does about twelve, thirteen hundred gross. Rent's a hundred and two. The problem, of course, is the supermarkets. That's what I wanna ask you. If I get together with a coupla other merchants, make our own supermarket...

dialogue.raw_text: What about the time she wanted to make an old-fashioned Italian dinner for my brother, but you wouldn't let her!?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with her own temper) Waddaya talking about?!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Once a month you couldn't let her use the kitchen!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I told her she could use the kitchen any time she wanted...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...You hadda be the boss inna kitchen alla time!

dialogue.raw_text: She don't wanna use my pots and pans!

dialogue.raw_text: So Tommy...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Waddaya want me to do, go out and buy a whole new setta pots and pans?!

dialogue.raw_text: Tommy, gimme a coupla minutes, because I promised Mr. Gazzara I'd let him know tomorrow. See, what I wanna know, Tom, if a buncha individual retail merchants get together, how does it operate? On individual mark- ups? You know what I mean? Say I'm the butcher and Aldo Capelli, he's the dairyman and grocer, so suppose I mark up thirty-five percent, but he works on forty, so...

dialogue.raw_text: No, I don't know. That's why I'm asking you.

dialogue.raw_text: Take the baby, will you?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wadda you wanna buy a shop for, will you tell me? You gotta good job, you got no wife, you got no responsibilities. Boy, I wish I was you, boy. Waddaya wanna tie yourself down with a shop? What's he want? Five thousand down? You're gonna have to carry a mortgage sixty, seventy bucks a month. A mortgage anna note from the bank. For Pete's sake, you're a single man with no responsibilities. Stay that way, boy. Take my advice.

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you see, Thomas I figure the big problem is the supermarkets. But Patsy's shop, that's a specialized trade. The supermarkets don't carry Italian meat.

dialogue.raw_text: Who buys Italian meat anymore? You think my wife buys Italian meat? (throws a baleful glance at his wife) She goes to the A&P, picks up some lamb chops wrapped in cellophane, opens up a canna peas, and that's dinner, boy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, all you wanna eat is that greasy stuff your mother makes.

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I understand the problem about the supermarkets, but I was talking to this girl last night, and she made the point that a likeable personality is a valuable business asset.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure. This girl said...

dialogue.raw_text: What girl, what does she know? (he whirls on his wife again) Why don't you let her hold the baby once in a while?! Your mother, boy, she wantsa take the kid for a day, that's fine!

dialogue.raw_text: (her temper flaring again) Your mother handles the kid like he was a yoyo!

direction.raw_text: . The two old sisters sit at the kitchen table, two untouched cups of coffee in front of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Catherine nods bleakly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty comes in from the living room, a little down after his session with Thomas and Virginia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty goes to the sink to get himself a glass of water. He examines a piece of plaster that has fallen from the ceiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Pilletti exchanges a brief frightened glance with her sister.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sends another frightened look at her sister and follows Marty out into the living room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . PILLETTI Hey, I come home from your house last night, Marty was here with a girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . PILLETTI Marty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your son Marty?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . PILLETTI Well, what Marty you think is gonna be here in this house with a girl?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Were the lights on?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . PILLETTI Oh sure. (frowns at her sister) This girl is a college graduate.

dialogue.raw_text: They're the worst. College girls are one step from the streets. They smoke like men inna saloon. My son Joseph, his wife, you know, she types onna typewriter. One step from the streets, I tell you. Mrs. Pilletti ponders this philosophy for a moment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . PILLETTI That's the first time Marty ever brought a girl to this house. She seems like a nice girl. I think he has a feeling for this girl. You heard him sing. He been singing like that all morning.

Then he's gonna say, "Hey, Ma, wadda we need this old house? Why don't we sell this old house, move into a nicer parta town? A nice little apartment?"

dialogue.raw_text: . PILLETTI I don't sell this house, I tell you that. This is my husband's house. I had six children in this house.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You will see. A coupla months, you gonna be an old lady, sleeping onna couch in her daughter-in-law's house.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . PILLETTI Catherine, you are a blanket of gloom. Wherever you are, the rain follows. Someday, you gonna smile, and we gonna declare a holiday.

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Ma, waddaya say, it's getting a little late.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . PILLETTI Sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Boy, this place is really coming to pieces. (turning to his mother) You know, Ma, I think we oughta sell this place. The whole joint's going to pieces. The plumbing is rusty. Everything. I'm gonna have to replaster the whole ceiling now. You know what we oughta do? We oughta get one of those new apartments they're building down on Southern Boulevard. A nicer parta town, you know?...You all set, Ma?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . PILLETTI I'm all set.

direction.raw_text: . Marty, his mother, Thomas and Virginia with the baby file down the porch to the street on their way to church. Marty and his mother are both troubled. The anger has left both Thomas and Virginia, but they are both silent. At the far end of the alleyway, as they reach the street, Virginia puts her free arm through her husband's elbow. Thomas looks briefly at her and they exchange a look of commiseration. Everyone turns and disappears off into the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: SHOT of the church establishes that stage of Sunday morning between the nine and ten o'clock masses. People flock around the doors of the church.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The parishioners are making their ways to the door. A few silent penitents still kneel here and there in the long empty rows of pews. The large, almost empty church is filled now with organ MUSIC. Both Marty and his mother seem a little depressed as they stand at the doorway just inside the church, as the nine o'clock mass people flow out, and the first of the ten o'clock mass people file in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A nearby kneeling penitent looks disapprovingly at Mrs. Pilletti and shushes her. The mother nods briefly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty frowns but remains silent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's Mrs. Pilletti's turn to frown. A silence. She turns back to Marty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty turns, on the verge of anger with his mother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A silence hangs between them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The kneeling woman shushes them again. By now the nine o'clock worshipers have filed out, and Marty joins the flow of ten o'clock people moving in. His mother turns back to him again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They continue down the aisle of the church.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. An hour later, the after-mass CROWD is there. It's a little more crowded than weekdays. A WOMAN with a glass of beer in one hand, rocks a baby carriage with the other. Marty enters the bar, moves along, ad-libbing "Hello" to someone at the bar, gets the attention of Lou, the bartender.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns away from the bar annoyed, notes Ralph, sitting alone in one of the booths, reading the Sunday comics. Marty ambles over to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The abruptness of the question rather startles Marty. It is not an expression he would normally associate with an evening with Clara.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He feels very ill at ease and a little guilty for defending himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He moves back down the bar and goes out into the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . AFTERNOON Marty is seated at the dining room table. He has removed his jacket, tie and shirt, even his shoes, and is making himself comfortable over a late Sunday lunch. With him are Angie and Joe, the Critic. Lounging in a chair but not at the table is Leo.

direction.raw_text: This doesn't prevent him from filching a second piece of rissole.

direction.raw_text: Marty looks down at his watch, then stands and starts for the phone, sitting on a chest of drawers at the other end of the room.

direction.raw_text: Joe, having finished his dissertation on Mickey Spillane, is now studying another girlie magazine. He proffers an opened page to Marty, who stands over by the phone.

direction.raw_text: He turns away sulking. Marty doesn't pick up the phone but returns to his seat, upset.

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT CLOSE ON television screen. Ed Sullivan is on, indicating the time is a little after half past seven. CAMERA PULLS BACK, disclosing Clara, Mr. and Mrs. Snyder in their living room. Apparently the Sullivan show is very funny at the moment, for the television audience roars with laughter. CAMERA MOVES IN CLOSE ON Clara. Another ROAR of LAUGHTER from the television that Clara watches, although her eyes are flooded with tears, several of which have already traced wet paths down her cheeks. Another ROAR of laughter.

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. Marty, Mrs. Pilletti and Catherine are eating silently at the table. Catherine reads an Italian newspaper as she eats.

direction.raw_text: Suddenly he pauses, sharply aware of the repetition in his life. Mrs. Pilletti is also aware of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They eat silently a moment.

dialogue.raw_text: . PILLETTI So what are you gonna do tonight, Marty?

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know, Ma. I'm all knocked out. I think I'll just hang arounna house and watch...

direction.raw_text: -UP of Marty leaning against the wall in front of the bar. A group of young men lounge about, killing time. Angie, Leo and Joe are among them. There are perhaps four or five other young MEN, loosely divided into two groups. The group that concerns us has Marty and the others mentioned and GEORGE, a young man in a sport jacket.

dialogue.raw_text: What time is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: About eight o'clock.

dialogue.raw_text: It'll take an hour anna hour back, and the whole evening's gone.

dialogue.raw_text: What's playing on Fordham Road? I think there's a good picture in the Loew's Paradise.

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, let's go down Seventy-Second Street, walk around. We're sure to wind up with something.

direction.raw_text: -UP of Marty, his head down, his eyes closed. The group continues their dialogue back and forth. Their VOICES can be heard as Marty's head slowly comes up.

direction.raw_text: A fury rises in Marty's face. He cries out at them.

dialogue.raw_text: (off-screen) I'll never forgive LaGuardia for cutting out burlesque outta New York City...

dialogue.raw_text: "What are you doing tonight?"... "I don't know, what are you doing?!"...

direction.raw_text: S over to the others who, at this outburst, stare at Marty astounded.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has said this in tones so loud that it attracts the attention of the few PEOPLE on the street. A little embarrassed by the attention he's getting, he turns, opens the door to the bar, and goes into it. After a stunned moment, Angie hurries after him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (continuing) The burlesque! Loew's Paradise! Miserable and lonely! Miserable and lonely and stupid! What am I, crazy or something?! I got something good here! What am I hanging around with you guys for?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . Marty marches the length of the room toward the phone booths in the rear. CAMERA ANGLES to disclose Angie right behind him. Marty is about to enter one of the phone booths, but he stops as Angie hurries up to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty pauses, one foot in the booth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marty has been fishing in his pocket for his address book. He opens it to its proper page and steps decisively into the phone booth. Nearby, Angie prowls around outside the booth. The booth door is open. Marty starts to dial. A hush fills the room except for the CLICKING of the telephone dial.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Watsa matter with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't like her. My mother don't like her. She's a dog, and I'm a fat, ugly little man. All I know is I hadda good time last night. I'm gonna have a good time tonight. If we have enough good times together, I'm gonna go down on my knees and beg that girl to marry me. If we make a party again this New Year's, I gotta date for the party. You don't like her, that's too bad.
